prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Thermal Sunyaev-Zel'dovich in B4
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Main array+ACA observation of the SZE at the signal negative peak frequency with a mosaic of the whole cluster area in the 125-141 GHz frequency range.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We propose to mosaic the cluster region in TDM in band 4 with IF at 133 GHz in order to include the SZE signal negative peak at 128.4GHz. The combination of main array and ACA allows to image the substructures angular scale ranges: the 80-200 kpc core radiiof of the substructures in Cl~J0152-1357 correspond to 10-30 arcsec at its z=0.84. Including also the details obtained with the main array in the range 5-10 arcsec, comparable to the XMM-Newton images (Maughan et al. 2006), we will unambiguously identify and measure the properties of the merging structures, calculate the impact parameters, and disentangle any instrumental limitation in the X-ray-SZE signal comparison. The smaller angular scales will also help in identifying pointlike positive signals contaminating the SZE signal that have to be removed.
The 3.5x3 arcmin region that we aim to map in band 4 includes the 3 main subclumps and the region where the two merging direction crosses (the SE and SW subclump that were not included in the ATCA observations). The mosaic of this region of the cluster requires 33 pointings for the ACA and 85 with the 12m array.
On the basis of the ATCA observations we performed we estimate that the negative peak of the signal on the 10-30 arcsec angular scales for the NE peak should be about -2.5 mJy at 140 GHz. The NE subclump core radius is 30 arcsec. According to the X-ray data analysis by Maughan et al. (2006) that estimated temperature and density maps, the SZE in the SW and SE subclumps should be at most a factor of 3 fainter than in the NE subclump, but on smaller angular scales (the SW clump core radius is 11 arcsec). Hence, by observing down to 0.16 mJy rms (averaging over the 7.5 GHz continuum bandwidth) we expect to properly map to a SNR>5 the SZE in the two main subclumps (the NE and SW) and their merging region and to get strong indications for the SE clump and its interaction with the NE one.
As a complementary serendipitous observations, the chosen spectral setup in band 4 might offer the opportunity to map the CO(2-1) transition at 125.7 GHz that is expected to be large enough to be resolved in at least 5 channels with the TDM spectral resolution. This signal cannot easily be predicted on the basis of the current knowledge of our target, but, if detected, it will allow us to investigate the rate of star formation in a not yet virialized galaxy cluster.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Dust distribution in B6
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: 12m array observation of the dust distribution due to star formation in the cluster Cl0152-1357 close to the SZE signal null point at 218 GHz with a mosaic of the regions of the cluster enclosing the peaks of galaxy number density.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We expect that the dust emission in this cluster is mostly located in the position of star forming galaxies and their surroundings.
Hence, we assume that its signal appears on clumpy structures on angular scales smaller than those of interest for the SZE.
To investigate the contamination to the SZE signal due to dust we propose to observe it close to the null point of the SZE spectrum in band 6, where also the radio emission is negligible. Hence, by setting the IF at 225 GHz we will enclose in one of our basebands the 218 GHz null point for the SZE signal in order to minimize its contribution and measure only the continuum dust signal in TDM.
To properly correct the SZE signal for the dust contamination effect it is necessary to observe the galaxy signal down to a sensitivity at least an order of magnitude higher than that used for the SZE signal. Scaling the signal of star-forming galaxies to z=0.84, we estimate that the band 6 dust signal is about an order of magnitude brighter than in band 4. Hence, we need to reach the same 0.16mJy rms also in band 6. We are not considering any effect due to clustering (that is most likely present in clusters, but difficult to estimate in our case under the effect of merging and gravitational collapses), that will locally improve our sensitivity. As we associate dust to galaxies we can limit our band 6 map to the region that encloses the peaks of galaxy distribution (see figures attached to the science case), the three main subclumps and the merging fronts of Cl0152-1357. For this reason we draw an 83 Nyquist-spaced-pointing custom mosaic which overlays such regions.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We propose the observation of the Sunyaev-Zel'dovich effect (SZE) substructure in the high redshift (z=0.834) massive galaxy cluster ClJ0152-1357 in band 4, close to the negative peak of the SZE signal. Observations of the cluster in several spectral bands showed a complex structure, with several subclumps and traces of merging events. 18 GHz ATCA observations (Massardi et al. 2010) confirmed that the peak of SZE signal is significantly displaced from the X-ray peak possibly because of a major merging of the subclumps. Thanks to its high redshift, high mass, and electron temperature and density, ClJ0152-1357 is a good target to investigate the interacting substructures in a cluster in the early stages of its evolution through the observation of SZE with ALMA main array and ACA in band 4. In addition, we will also have the chance to map in band 4 the CO(2-1) spectral line emission,tracer of star formation in the cluster galaxies. By following up the cluster inner region also in band 6, where the SZE signal has its null point, we aim to study the star formation distribution in this complex system and the contamination to the SZ signal due to dust emission.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Cosmology and the High Redshift Universe

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: Institute of Radioastronomy of Bologna, INAF
